title: Specialist anti-mafia police heading to Celtic Park to monitor 300 Lazio ultras in Europa League tie
text:
Specialist anti-mafia cops are 'flying to Scotland in a bid to prevent notorious Lazio fans from causing trouble' ahead of Thursday's Europa League clash with Celtic.

The squad of elite 'Special Operations' officers will monitor around 300 of Lazio ultras before, during and after the group match in Glasgow, according to The Sun.

The decision to call in the specialist unit follows UEFA's order to shut sections of Lazio's Stadio Olimpico ground for next month's return fixture due to their supporters' fascist gestures and racist chants during a group game against Rennes.

Specialist anti-mafia cops are being flown in to Scotland to monitor Lazio supporters

300 Lazio ultras are expected to travel to Glasgow for Thursday night's Europa League match

Sources in Italy told The Sun that there will be a high police presence for Thursday's game amid fears of violent clashes breaking out between both sets of supporters.

Scottish cops will escort the Italian fans to Celtic Park with 1,500 expected to make the journey over for Thursday's match.

The Sun claim an insider told them: 'The concern is this ultras group is highly organised. A great deal of resources will be put in place to ensure fans are kept apart.'

Police presence will be high amid fears of clashes between Celtic and Lazio supporters

UEFA ordered Lazio to shut a section of their ground due to racist chants against Rennes

Lazio officials pleaded with their supporters to behave in Glasgow this week and warned that there will be a zero-tolerance approach to any racist abuse directed at Celtic's players.

They said: 'Scottish law punishes any act of violence, racism, xenophobia and intolerance, especially during sporting events.

'We appeal to the fans' civic sense to avoid behaviour that can generate reactions from local authorities.'

The Serie A side identified and banned 20 supporters for racial abuse during their Europa League victory over Rennes earlier this month.
